title: Bride-to-be fleeced fiance and his 30 mates out of £11,000 stag do cash
text:

A lying bride-to-be who fleeced her fiance and his 30 closest pals by stealing their Ibiza stag party cash has avoided jail.

Stunned Chris Mahone only realised “deceitful and callous” Rachel Doran had ripped them off as they got ready for take off.

The unsuspecting stag party discovered their flight tickets from Leeds Bradford airport were all fake.

With rising panic the stags called ahead to the Ibiza Rocks hotel on the party isle and found that no bookings had been made.

Nuclear process worker Chris, 29, realised with horror that while they had been planning their wedding, his fiance had secretly been spending the £11,160 stag do cash on herself.

(Image: MDM)

When he rang from the airport to ask her what had happened to the cash, Doran told him she was pregnant.

But her internet history later revealed she had searched the words "fake ultrasound picture maker."

Doran, 32, fled the home they shared in Cleator Moor, Cumbria, when Chris told her the wedding was off and he never wanted to see her again.

Doran avoided prison at Carlisle crown court on Tuesday after she admitted stealing from the stag party and forging Jet2.com flight documents.

(Image: PA)

The court was told that Doran and Mr Mahone were childhood friends who had met at school, later starting a relationship.

Their wedding date was set for December 2017 and the groom had planned a three day stag party for September.

Doran was made the "treasurer" for the stag do and helped organise it along with two of Mr Mahone's best friends.

She collected £360 from each of the stags and was supposed to bank it to pay for their flights and hotels.

Instead she frittered it away on herself and online gambling sites.

(Image: Internet Unknown)

Gerard Rogerson, prosecuting, told the court the stag party met at Cleator Moor Celtic Football Club on September 7th 2017.

They first realised something was wrong when the bus failed to turn up to take them to the airport.

They persuaded the bus company there had been a mistake and a driver came out to take them to Leeds Bradford.

Mr Rogerson said: "A member of the group had got there before the bus and said there was a problem, his documents had not been recognised and this cast doubt on the entire booking arrangement.

"He rang the Ibiza Rocks Hotel and discovered that no bookings had been made.

"It became clear the Jet2 booking confirmation form was a fake document and it was then that Mr Mahone tried to ring Miss Doran on her mobile phone but she did not answer initially.

"Later in the day Miss Doran phoned him wanting to talk and he told her to leave him alone as he wanted nothing to do with her.

"She texted him later and told him she was pregnant."

(Image: PA)

A victim impact statement from Mr Mahone said: "I felt so let down. I trusted her and was getting ready to settle down and spend the rest of my life with her.

"I loved her at the time and I have not been able to move on because I cannot trust anyone else in the way I trusted Rachel.

"I am trying to move on but I find it difficult to talk to women because I am scared of getting hurt.

"My friends are gutted, they don't want the money back, they just want justice done.

“My friends could have turned on me but they didn't.

"I don't want to see Rachel again I just want some closure.

"Maybe when she has been sentenced I will regain some of my confidence and kickstart my life again.

"I want Rachel to learn from what she has done."

(Image: PA)

Doran was unable to tell police what she had done with the money but said she had been getting "deeper and deeper" into debt.

Kim Whittlestone, representing Doran, said her client had suffered a number of miscarriages and the impact on her mental health was significant.

"During that time she was seeking to please others to bolster her own self worth."

She said her client had ended up in a hostel where she had made a "serious attempt" to take her own life.

Ms Whittlestone told the court that she had in fact been pregnant as she told Mr Mahone but had terminated the pregnancy.

Judge Nicholas Barker told Doran: "You have acted in a deceitful and callous way.

“You must have known this would be found out and would come crashing down around you” and added: “the real victim was your fiance”.

Factory worker Doran from Egremont, Cumbria, was given a 15 month sentence, suspended for two years and was ordered to repay £3,600 in compensation to be split equally by the stag party.
description: Rachel Doran had secretly been spending the money on herself and online gambling sites
